titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-05-07 19:26:01 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The collection contains appraisals for properties located on Duffield Street and Willoughby Street in Downtown Brooklyn by Edmund B. Brooks, William A. Stewart, and Jacques O. Tuchler. Included with the appraisals are photographs and maps of the properties. The appraisals were conducted in relation to the urban renewal and redevelopment efforts underway in Downtown Brooklyn during this period.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The collection was formally accessioned in 1980.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Each of the three reports in this collection is housed in its own folder.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Downtown Brooklyn real estate appraisals, 1980.009, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2024.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains appraisals for properties located at 211-221 Duffield Street and 110-114 Willoughby Street by Edmund B. Brooks, 201-221 Duffield Street and 106-114 Willoughby Street by William A. Stewart, and 201-221 Duffield Street and 106-114 Willoughby Street by Jacques O. Tuchler. Included with the appraisals are photographs, floorplans, and maps of the properties. The appraisals were conducted in relation to the urban renewal and redevelopment efforts underway in Downtown Brooklyn during this period.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
